title: 102nd Problem 2016
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfying "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \dfrac 84 = \dfrac{x-1}5 ."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Check out the set: 2016 Problems."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is wrong with this "proof" that 1 = 0?
z = 1.
1 = 1 x 1.
So, z x z = z
z(z-1) = 0
z = 0.
But... z = 1!!!
So, 0 = 1?"}]}]}

title: 103 trigonometric problems from
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be positive numbers satisfying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y+z=xyz"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the maximum value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\displaystyle \\sum_\\text{cyclic} \\dfrac x{\\sqrt{1+x^2}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\dfrac {a\\sqrt b}c "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are positive integers with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" coprime and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" square-free, find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\tan A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=\tan B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z = \tan C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y+z=xyz"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\tan A + \tan B + \tan C = \tan A \tan B \tan C "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  This means that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the angles of a triangle.  Then, we have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} S & = \sum_{cyc} \frac x{\sqrt{1+x^2}} = \sum_{cyc} \frac {\tan A}{\sqrt{1+\tan^2 A}} = \sum_{cyc} \frac {\tan A}{\sqrt{\sec^2 A}} \\ & = \sum_{cyc} \frac {\tan A}{\sec A} = \sum_{cyc} \frac {\sin A}{\cos A}\cdot \cos A = \sum_{cyc} \sin A \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \implies S & = \sin A + \sin B + \sin C \\ & = \sin A + \sin B + \sin (180^\circ - (A+B)) \\ & = \sin A + \sin B + \sin (A+B) \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For a fixed "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is maximum when:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \frac {\partial S}{\partial B} & = 0 \\ \dfrac \partial{\partial B} (\sin A + \sin B + \sin (A+B)) & = 0 \\ \cos B + \cos (A+B) & = 0 \\ \cos B & = - \cos (A+B) = \cos (180^\circ - A - B) \\ \implies B & = 180^\circ - A - B \\ \implies B & = 90^\circ - \frac A2 \\ \implies S_{max}(A) & = \sin A + \sin \left(90^\circ - \frac A2 \right) + \sin \left(A + 90^\circ - \frac A2 \right) \\ & = \sin A + 2 \cos \frac A2 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"And "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is maximum when: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \frac {\partial S_{max}(A)}{\partial A} & = 0 \\ \frac \partial{\partial A} \left(\sin A + 2 \cos \frac A2 \right) & = 0 \\ \cos A - \sin \frac A2 & = 0 \\ \cos A & = \sin \frac A2 \\ \implies A & = 60^\circ \\ \implies B & = 90^\circ - \frac {60^\circ}2 = 60^\circ \\ \implies C & = 60^\circ \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies S_{max} = 3\sin 60^\circ  = \dfrac {3\sqrt 3}2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies a+b+c = 3+3+2 = \boxed{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=tan(A) , y=tan(B) , z=tan(C)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" .Then given condition reduces to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"tan(A)+tan(B)+tan(C)=tan(A)tan(B)tan(C)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is true if A,B,C are angles of a triangle (or more generally, their sum is an integral multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So we need to maximize "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"sin(A)+sin(B)+sin(C)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"which turns out to be if all angles are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\pi}{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or the triangle is equilateral."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus the maximum value is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+c=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Divide 3628800! by 5^n till the quotient value is less than 1 and then add all the quotient values that we get 3628800 when divided by 5^n.
After doing this , we get the answer as 907197. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Please up vote if you like this."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Divide 3628800! by 5^n  till the quotient value is less than 1
 and then add all the quotient values that we get 3628800 when divided by 5^n"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Divisor is fun
104th Problem 2016
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solve the quadratic equation:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" { 4x }^{ 2 }+8x+8=4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Check out the set: 2016 Problems."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4x^2 +8x + 8 = 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow 4x^2 + 8x +4 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Solve it with the quadratic formula : "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For a quadratic equation of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ax^2 + bx + c = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the solutions are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_1, _2 = \dfrac { -b \pm     \sqrt {b^2 - 4ac} } {2a}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, applying the formula."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 4, b= 8, c = 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x_1, _2 = \dfrac {-8 \pm \sqrt {8^2 - 4 \times 4 \times 4} } { 2 \times 4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8^2 - 4 \times 4 \times4 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \dfrac{-8}{2 \times 4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" = \dfrac{-8}{-8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= - \dfrac{8}{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= \boxed{-1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 107,105 point musings
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large n^2 = \\overline{10a\\:b0c}, \\qquad  a,b,c \\not = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many "},{"type":"text","text":"perfect squares","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" are of the form shown in the formula above?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                    "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Relevant wiki: Perfect Squares, Cubes, and Powers","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"101\:101 \leq n^2 \leq 109\:909"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" it follows by taking square roots that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"318 \leq n \leq 331."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
We can rule out "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"320"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"330"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" immediately because their squares would end in zero; and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"325"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" because its square would end in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"25"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the remaining 11 numbers, it helps to know that the last two digits of the square is equal to the last two digits of the square of the last two digits; e.g. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"318^2 \equiv 18^2 \equiv 24"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" mod 100, etc."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As it turns out, none of the squares of these numbers has a zero at the tens position. Therefore the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{\text{zero, zilch, zip, naught, nada}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
